Name: Ada Morrison (Ada Morrison)
Address: P.O. Box 200
Birthplace: Warman, Grey Co., Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start homesteading in Eastern Canada? 1895
   Where did you settle homesteading? P.O. Box 200, Warman, Grey Co., Ont.
   How far had you been living before that? 10 miles
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
   How far was it to your nearest store? 10 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Every two weeks or when necessary
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, salt, pepper, prunes, dried apples, cornstarch, rice, raisins, currants, tea syrup.
   In what quantities did you buy? 10 pounds of sugar, 10 pounds of flour, 10 pounds of salt, 10 pounds of tea syrup.
   How much did you pay for each item? $1.00 per pound of sugar, $1.00 per pound of flour, $1.00 per pound of salt, $1.00 per pound of tea syrup.

2. FLOUR AND GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie's and graham
   Where did you get your flour? From a mill in Warman, Grey Co., Ont.
   In what quantities did you buy? 10 pounds
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $4.00
   How much did you use graham flour? 10 pounds
   Whole wheat flour? 10 pounds
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? 10 miles
   What year? 1895
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.50
   What other grain products did you use? Wheat, cornmeal, flour, rice, beans, peas
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
   How did you grind it? With a coffee grinder then crushed

Name: Ada Morrison (Ada Morrison)
Address: P.O. Box 246, Wapella, Sask.
Birthplace: Warman, Sask., Canada

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1900
Where did you set up housekeeping? 1876, 1878, 1882, N.E. of Wapella, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? N.E. of Prince Albert, Sask., S.S.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4-5, our two selves and two men
How far was it to your nearest store? 12 mi.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once in two weeks or when necessary
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, salt, pepper, prunes, dried apples, cornstarch, rice, raisins, currants, tea, syrup.

In what quantities did you buy it? 10 lbs. at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.60
How much did you use graham flour? It was creamy color, did not use much
Whole wheat flour? Not much unless for biscuits, ground the wheat fine
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 12 mi.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 26¢
What other grain products did you use? Shortening, little pigs, bran for cows
Cornmeal? Yes, for cake
Whole wheat? Yes
Farina? No
Other? Used wheat meal for porridge and cake
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, whenever we were able to buy a
How did you grind it? Not with a coffee grinder then crushed
Christian, Mrs. Ada (Mrs. J.)
Rooanville.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? prairie chicken, rabbits, ducks, wild turkeys, hares, and pork.

How did you get fresh meat? killed a hen, ducks, or chickens, caught fish when we could get to the lake, catched beef ring.

How often did you get fresh meat? once a week from beef ring.

How did you preserve meat? brine, cured pork, dried and packed in oats kept fresh, beef, pork, and fowl frozen in winter.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? yes

If so what year was it organized? 1914

Did you use game? yes

What kinds? wild ducks, prairie chicken, partridge, and jack rabbit.

For how long? just in the fall, used eggs, killed a hen.

What part did fish play in the family diet? usually could get a supply of fresh from the Indians in winter & spring.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? fresh

Kinds? pickerel, pike, white suckers, spring.

Did some fishing ourselves in the Deschutes river and later when we had a car we went to Powell Lake & to Oregon. cured some in a crock in salt. Tried canning some about 1916 which was very good, put beet juice in to give a pink color.

15. What was your favorite meal (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember? Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. Include the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

For example, in 1883, we had roast beef with gravy, rice pudding, creamed celery, boiled eggs, baked beans, brown bread, maple syrup, topped the tree and added the soup (slag).

Dinner included mashed potatoes, fried pork, bread butter, and baked cinnamon apples with cream.

Supper: vegetable soup, tea biscuit, bread butter, and apple sauce. Nov. 1880. Family: Melissa age 11, Herbert age 9, Ada age 5, Albert age 3, Wesley age 2, Father & Mother.

16. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

For example, in 1883, we served Christmas dinner: turkey, roasted rabbit with dressing, some sort of steamed pudding with sauce, bread and butter, mother's brother and his wife 4 months, Melissa 14, Herbert 12, Ada 8, Dec. 7, Albert 5, Wesley 3, Grace 2. Had a poplar tree decked with colored paper saved from shoe boxes.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

The first year, mother & father were in the west; we only had 12 acres of grain and the gophers were so plentiful, in spite of our snaring and trapping, drowning them out etc. They ate it nearly all. Saved a bit for seed and forage meat. Had a year supply of flour, syrup and dried apples with us from Oct. But in coming out our train was wrecked between St. Paul & Winnipeg, a signal, can of coal oil got spilled and our supplies got more or less spoiled so it was only dire necessity forced us to use them. Not much money to get more. We grew a winter supply of potatoes but they got frozen. Mother put them inside of all into a large crock pot with boiling water and cooked them. They were sweet but we enjoyed them with roast rabbit and brown gravy. Had only one cow, sow with her litter, ox in which got killed in the wreck bought a mule before selling the next year; done some more breaking, plowed with a pony & cow. Drive to Qu'Appelle valley 1/4 mile to pick saskatoons, cooked & dried them in ovens in the sun.

30. What was the most challenging aspect of growing up in Indiana?
my mother when she was young bought all her necessary groceries by exchanging or selling butter, eggs, chickens, ducks early vegetables, and corned beef. Not all our wants were supplied, many times we went without butter, eggs or chicken to have enough to buy some print, shirting or stockings usually wool as we kept stockings socks and mitts for 10 cents. After I was married in 1908, I did the same though we never went quite so short. I packed butter and sold it privately for 10¢ a lb. Eggs for 5¢ each, a dozen. Chicken for $1 and 10¢ lb., for a good many years, in 1903-1906 farmers all had to run a bill at the store through the summer. It was risky business for the store keeper who carried it for several years losing in the end. Those people who did that were extravagant and careless, machinery had to be bought on time very often and if the crop was badly frozen or ruined it was just as bad on both sides. Our first year was bad we bought a team of horses harness and binder depending on the crop to pay for them. Our grain was all scattered over the road into ditches etc., with a cyclone and...
Hail, it came the day we bought the horses and harness; it was a very disheartening sight. We met on the morning of the day our grain was nearly all cut but the stubble was beaten into the ground. You knew how badly the grain was needed in the market. My husband went right back the next day to the man from whom we got the horses and asked him to take them back, as paying for them was out of the question. So he took them back. The harness maker let us keep the harness & the machine agent, the binder until we could pay. We paid part that fall and earned some money by going out harvesting with the neighbors to pay fellows who took the risk. In 1928 we were able to pay off the mortgage on the house. It was good to get back all the money we had lost.

We made most of our clothing except pants overalls underclothing for men and tops coats smocks and men's suits. I sewed everything for my 6 children until they were 14 or 15. I made shirts for myself up to 1930. Did not sleep sheep but some of our neighbors did. I spun the wool into yarn, twisted it to make comforter. I was glad when in about 1932 I could buy wool balls all ready to use for $2.50. The first print I bought to line a quilt about 1924 was 8¢ a yd.; good heavy 36" stuff.

We worked hard for everything we had. Those days no dole, if crops were poor in 1923 my husband worked for his bread and 25¢ per day. Every child knew how to work. We were not running all over. Our social activities were centered around home and church. One of our neighbors kept a post office, when a mail man from Wapella brought the mail to Christians. In 1903 the C.P.R. built the railroad branch line and Rockville started. Not too long after we got our mail from there, Mrs Robert Christian named that district Prosperity, which is 6 mi west of Rockville. I was the first teacher in this district 1897-1899. Taught at Setlock N.E. corner. Was married to John Christian Aug 1900 and came back to live in Prosperity Dist where we made our home until 1946 when my husband died and I moved to town. During our life here we helped build a church and hall, served on church board. I was a member of the Prosperity H.M.C. organized in May 1907 also helped organize the I.S.W.A. Q.W.M. S. served as Pres. 4 Sec for several terms.

Children were members of larger families and were more obedient, worked so much than most children today. Very few used tobacco or liquor. A law forbid merchants selling the stuff to juniors. Now it is a common sight to see children on the way to school smoking a cigarette. In my opinion it is a most subtle enemy of mankind. Know one little boy of six who smokes regularly. He is making little progress in school and is very much undersize. Another thing I notice is that the women take the lead in training children for leadership. The teenage girls can take a meeting, give papers on different topics and boys don't know...

The harness maker let us keep the harness & the machine agent, the lender, and earned some money by going out to work on other farms. We were able to pay off the mortgage on our land. We made most of our clothing except pants for the stock in the pasture near about 1935, up to 1938. We made most of our clothing except pants overalls underclothing for men and top coats, smocks and overalls. I sewed everything for my 6 children until they were 14 or 15. I made shirts for the men too. I did not have sheep but some of our neighbors did and spun the wool into yarn, twisted it to make comforter. I was glad when in about 1932 I could buy wool balls at a ready to use for $2.50. I bought print to line a quilt about 1934. I gave 8¢ a yd., good heavy 36” stuff. We worked hard for every thing we had in those days. No dole of crops were poor. In 1937 my husband worked for his bread and 25¢ per day. Every child knew how to work. We were not running all over. Robert Christiansen, in 1903, the C.P.R. built the railroad branch line and Rosamond started. Not long after we got our mail from there. Mr. Robert Christiansen named that district Prosperity, which is 6 mi. west of Rosamond. I was the first teacher in that district, 1897-1899. I taught at Titlock & Gunfell. I was married to John Christian August 1900 and came back to live in Prosperity Dist. where we made our home until 1946 when my husband died and I moved to town. During our life there we helped build a church and school, served on church board. I was a member of the PineSpirit H.M.C., organized in May 1907 also helped organize the L.D.S. & W.M.S. served as Pres. & Sec. for several terms.

A law forbid merchants selling the stuff to juniors. Now it is a common sight to see children on the way to school smoking a cigarette. In my opinion it is a most subtle enemy of mankind. How we little boys of six who smoke regularly. We are making little progress in school and is very much under size. Another thing I notice is that the women take the lead in training children for leadership. The teenage girls can take a meeting, give papers on different topics and boys don't hence...
Hail, it came the day we bought the horses and harness. It was a very disheartening sight when we met on returning home. Our grain was nearly all cut but the stubble was beaten into the ground so you knew how badly the grain was shelled on the main. My husband went right back the next day to take them back, as paying for them was out of the question. So he took them back. The harness maker let us help pay the harness and the machine agent. The binder until we could pay. We paid part that fall and earned some money by going out looking out for sheep. We were able to pay fellow who took the rent. In 1928 we were able to pay as we went, unless for something expensive which was carried for a month or so. It was good to get back all for the stock in the pasture for about 1935. Up to 1938 we made most of our clothing except pants overalls under clothing for men and top coats smocks and men's suits. I sewed everything for my children until they were 14 or 15. Made quilts for the men too dresses nighties slips and aprons for myself up to 1920 did not have sheep but some of our neighbors did and spun the wool into yarn. Teased it to make comforters. I was glad when in about 1932 I could buy wool batts all ready to use for $2.50. The first print I bought to make a quilt about 1926 gave 84 a yd. Good heavy 36" stuff. We worked hard for every thing we had in those days no dole if crops were poor. In 1923 my husband worked for his board and 25¢ per day. Every child knew how to work. We were not running all over. Our social activities were centered around home and church. One of our neighbors kept a post office when a mail man from Wapella came left the mail at Christiansburg. In 1903 the C.P.R. built the Keralla branch line and Rosamond started. Not long after we got our mail from there. Mrs Robert Christian named that district Prosperity, which is 6 mi west of Beaconville. I was the first teacher in this district 1897-1898. Taught at Keralla N. Guernsey. Was married to John Christian Aug 1900 and came back to live in Prosperity Dist where we made our home until 1940 when my husband died and I moved to town. During our life there we helped build a church and hall, served on church board. I was a member of the Prosperity H.M.C. organized in May 1907 also helped organize the H.M.C. & W.M.C. served as pres. 7 sec for several terms.

Children were members of larger families and were more obedient, worked two more cheerfully than most children today. Very few used tobacco or liquor. A few fond merchants selling the stuff to juniors. Now it is a common sight to see children on the way to school smoking a cigarette. In my opinion it is a most subtle enemy of mankind. Know one little boy of six who smokes regularly. He is making little progress in school and is very much under size. Another thing I notice is that the women talk the lead in training children for leadership. The teenage girls can take a meeting, give papers on different topics and boys don't know...
lack of men leaders most everywhere. In most every district there are H.M.C.'s or societies of some sort conducted by women, none by the men who are content to sit by the fire and smoke and let the rest of the world go by. Now that women have taken to the 'weed', what will the next generation, if there is any, be like. There is something wrong somewhere or humanity could not need a poisonous weed to satisfy. My mother & father had very little education only read and write a little. But we went to school & S.S. When we came west in 1883 one of our bachelor neighbors taught us to read. There was 2 & us and 6 other children went to his house. He always went away in winter so my oldest sister taught us at home. Another family from England came, he taught and we had S.S. in our house. There was not enough children close enough to get two to get a school built so we moved back to Ont. for 5 yrs; then came back N. of Grenfell. Father was eligible for a 2nd homestead & got it. (over)

This is rather a rambling account. If I had my mother's papers and bills could have done better. What education I got—after 1893—was got in Brandon H.S. and Grenfell H.S., finished at Regina Normal. The principal of the H.S. was a good man and instructed us in right living as well as how to teach it.

Yours very sincerely,

Mrs. Ada E. Christian

for the Prosperity H.M.C.

Rosamville

Sask.
